ends to favour wealthier and higher
Broader, more inclusive sharing of costs and burdens is seen as a way to enhance equity in procedures
Ultimately, equity consequences depend on how costs and benefits are initially incur
are shared as per social contracts
agreements. The literature suggests a relation
between the effectiveness of cooperative action and
the perception of fairness of such arrangements.
put forward a wide variety of ind
icators and approaches for explaining the fairness and ambition of their
NDCs, reflecting the broader range of perspectives found in the moral philosophical literature cited
at adaptation and financing issues take on greater salience
in the national perspectives reflected in the NDCs.
Topics of equity and fairness have begun to receive a greater amount of attention within the energy and
climate literature, namely through the a
frequently envision justice and equity as an ethical imperative, justice also possesses
g deeper and more socially acceptable mitigation efforts
A concrete focal point on these issues has been that of “just transition”
transformational changes entailed in moving from a high
one behind’, i.e., ensuring (sufficiently) equitable transition for the relevant affected individuals,
workers, communities, sectors, regions and countries
concept of a “just transition” owes its origin to
version of a just transition was called the “Superfund for Workers” modelled on the 1980 Superfund
program that designed federal funds for the clean
up of toxic substances from chemicals, mining and
. It was further taken up, for example in the collaboration
the International Trade Union Confederation (ITUC), the International Labour Organization (ILO) and
the UN Environmental Programme (UNEP) in promoting “green jobs” as integra
In recent years the concept of a “just transition” has gained
increased traction, for example incorporated in the outcome of the Rio+20 Earth Summit and more
recently recognised in the preamble of the Paris Agreement, which states “the imperative of a just
transition of the workforce and the creation of decent work and quality jobs in accordance with
Solidarity and Just Transition Silesia Declaratio
first introduced at COP24 in Poland
The literature identifies targeted and proactive measures from governments, agencies, and authorities
to ensure that any negative social, environmental or economic impacts of economy
minimised, whilst benefits are maximised for those disproportionally affected
While the precise definition varies by source, core elements tend to include: (1) investments in
research and early assessment of the social and employment impacts of climate policies
dialogue and democratic consultation of social
ve labour markets policies; and rights at work
investments; (7) realistic training/retraining programs that lead to decent work; (8) gender specific
